SafetyInspectionBy: San Bernardino County Hazardous Materials Division

_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: All Other Miscellaneous Chemical Product and Preparation Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Shield Packaging is a contract packager, manufacturing aerosol and liquid products.  The facility receives flammable gases, liquefied under pressure, by tank truck and places them in storage tanks. These flammable gases are used as ingredients in our products.



Details of storage tanks are as follows:

Tank No. 1:  Volume: 6,900 USG;  Content:  A-70 blend [54.7% Propane, 27.2% N-Butane, 18.1% Isobutane]

Tank No. 2:  Volume: 5,500 USG;  Content: A-46 blend [19.1% Propane, 80.9% Isobutane]

Tank No. 10:  Volume:  6,000 USG;  Content: Difluoroethane [R152a]

Tank No. 8:  Volume:  3,275 USG;  Content:  Dimethyl Ether [also known as Methyl Ether]



The unloading manifolds are adequately designed and approved by the CAL OSHA Pressure Vessel Division.  Each of the storage tanks are pressure vessels and are permitted by the same regulatory agency.



All tanks, pumps, piping, fittings, valves and associated safety devices are installed and maintained following NFPA-58 Code requirements and National LP Gas Association guide lines. We have excess flow and check valves in lines, as well as manual and automatic shut off valves.  The tanks are equipped with an excess flow valve and pressure relief valve.  We have maintenance procedures that prevent corrosion.  Storage tanks are typically filled to 85% of full capacity as a matter of internal policy to maintain a margin of safety.



Shield has written operating procedures for safe unloading and handling of chemicals and gases.  All bulk liquid chemicals are stored in diked containment areas.  These containment areas have manual drain valves. All valves on all tanks are closed when not in use. 



Shield has a robust preventive maintenance program that insures that the tanks and handling equipment remain in safe working condition. The employees are well trained to perform their particular job tasks in a safe and competent manner.



Shield is a non-responding facility.  The local Fire Department has been informed that they

would be summoned immediately as first responders.  All installations have been inspected and approved by local Fire Department.  The Fire Department conducts periodic walk through of the entire facility.  This enables them to prepare for adequate emergency response. Anticipated response time is short as the fire station is located less than a half mile away.  



The Emergency Response Plan outlines the necessary actions in the event of emergency scenarios.  If the emergency evacuation alarm is sounded, certain designated employees have pre-assigned duties while all other employees evacuate along a pre-determined route and gather at an assembly area.  Employees shall remain in the designated assembly area until instructed to return to their work stations by the Plant Manager or designee.  If a discharge cannot be controlled, or in the event of a fire, the Fire Department will be summoned immediately and all other required regulatory agencies will be notified.  We have made arrangements with an outside contractor to help with emergency response, if necessary.  Shield conducts periodic drills to maintain the necessary level of preparedness.



No accidental releases have occurred at the Shield facility which is also secured by a fence.



Our Worst Case scenario would be a vapor cloud explosion, resulting from a storage tank rupture due to overfilling and/or equipment failure.  

The Alternative Release scenario consists of a truck pull away during unloading, with the release of the contents of a 2 inches diameter, 20 feet long hose, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.

The USEPA's RMP Comp model has been used to estimate the distance to endpoints.

The Worst Case scenario for a vapor cloud explosion of the A-70 blend, is a distance to endpoint of 0.3 mile.

The Alternative Release scenario, resulting from a truck pull away/hose failure and a vapor cloud explosion of pure propane or isobutane, is a distance to endpoint of 0.01 mile.



MARPLOT (Mapping Application

for Response, Planning, and Local Operational Tasks), developed jointly by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) was used to obtain population estimates within the affected zones.  The estimate of residential population within a worst case scenario radius of 0.3 mile is 138.
